section.name: General information about Nividic and Javascript
section.p: This page contains contains information about how files are handled and other specifities of the Nividic Javascript version.

section.name: Files functions
section.p: As Javascript no define a standardized API to access to filesystem, Nividic is built-in with its own mecanism. In the nividic javascript version, file are usualy handled as a Java File Object.
To select a file, use the sf command (as Select File)
To select many file, use the ls command:

body.p: As in Java there is no mean to change the current directory. The path of file in coded in a Java File Object as the relative path from the startup dir or as the absolute path.
If you only want to show the names of the files of a dir, ou can use the dir command:
If you want to change the current dir, use the cd command and you get the current directory with pwd or cwd.

section.name: Working with scripts
section.p: You can load a script with the source function:
section.source:
js>source(sf("myscript.js")) Load script: myscript.js
js>source("myscript.js") Load script: myscript.js
section.p: You can use either a File Object or a String as parameter of this function. In addition, you can launch an editor for a file with the edit function:

subsection.name: comments
subsection.p: You can get a brief of the built-in command of the Nividic version of Javascript with help()
subsection.source:
js>help()
Command Description ======= =========== help() Display usage and help messages. source(file) Load JavaScript source file. edit(file) Edit a file. print([expr ...]) Evaluate and print expressions. about() Show information about this application. system(cmd) Execute a shell command. time([expr]) Get the running time of a expression. quit() Quit the shell.

subsection.name: comments
subsection.p: It seem that only C (/* My comment */) comments are working with the JavaScript engine.

subsection.name: Measure command running time
subsection.p: You can measure the running time of a command with the time command. This function returns the time in ms.

subsection.name: Get the current time
subsection.p: The currentTime() function return the numbers of seconds from the Unix/Java epoch.

subsection.name: Execute shell commands
subsection.p: You can run shell command using the system command:
subsection.source: js>system("uname -sv") Linux #1 PREEMPT Wed Jun 28 10:51:12 CEST 2006
